objects.name: Controls_Player2
objects.string:
Up Arrow for up
Down Arrow for Down

objects.name: Controls_Player1
objects.string:
W for up
A for Down

events.comment: The example uses a custom BatBounce extension for the bounce mechanic
maximize the window at the beginning
The paddles are anchored to the sides using anchor behavior
Player 1 movement
Player 1 movement
Limit the movement of the paddle between the two barriers (Top and Bottom)
Bounce of paddle
The spacial sound is set so that the sound comes from the side where the ball hits
Avoid making the ball move at the angle near to the right angles, so that the ball doesn't get stuck
Bounce of barrier
The Lose Zone objects are on both the sides (Left and Right). Streching to whole window's height. Lose Zone have ID object variables that identifies their side
ball Colliding with LoseZone, ID of Lose Zone is 1= Delete Ball, Add 1 to the score of player 2
The spacial sound is set so that the sound comes from the side where the ball misses
Change state of Game to Won if any one of the player's score is greater than 10
Change state of Game to NotStarted if both of the player's score is less than/equal to 10
ball Colliding with LoseZone, ID of Lose Zone is 1= Delete Ball, Add 1 to the score of player 1
The spacial sound is set so that the sound comes from the side where the ball misses
Change state of Game to Won if any one of the player's score is greater than 10
Change state of Game to NotStarted if both of the player's score is less than/equal to 10
The gui elements are anchored using the anchor behavior
Reduce opacity of gui elements when the ball or paddle are on top of them, to improve visiblity
Center the text on the x axis
Space is pressed, create the ball on a random point in the middle line on the Y axis, add ball a force towards a random angle
Change the Win Text according to who won
The spacial sound is set so that the sound comes from the side of the player which won
Re-Start the scene

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: @4ian
eventsFunctionsExtensions.description:
Provides an action to make the object bounce from another object it just touched. Add a permanent force to the object and, when in collision with another one, use the action to make it bounce realistically.

This *won't work* with Physics engine or Platformer characters. This is working with objects that are moved using actions or behaviors using **the forces**.
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: Bounce
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Provides an action to make the object bounce from another object it just touched. Add a permanent force to the object and, when in collision with another one, use the action to make it bounce realistically.

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Provides an action to make the object bounce from another object it just touched. Add a permanent force to the object and, when in collision with another one, use the action to make it bounce realistically.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: Bounce

eventsFunctions.description:
Bounce the object off another object it is currently colliding with, according to the angle and the speed of forces applied on the object.
Make sure to test for a collision between the two objects before launching this action. All the forces will be removed from the object, and a new permanent force will be added to make the object bounce.
eventsFunctions.name: BounceOff

events.comment:
To bounce the object realistically, we first separate it from the obstacle. The collision engine will do it by moving the object through the shortest "normal vector" of the edge that was collided.
We store the position of the object before being moved so that we know the angle of this "normal vector". Once we know it, we add a force in the direction of the normal vector, and we add the difference between the normal vector and the previous angle of movemement.

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: None
eventsFunctionsExtensions.description: Send the object back and set a direction opposed to the bat center to allow the player to aim.
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: BatBounce
